src_text.0: Quamquam te, Marce fili, annum iam audientem Cratippum, idque Athenis, abundare oportet praeceptis institutisque philosophiae propter summam et doctoris auctoritatem et urbis, quorum alter te scientia augere potest, altera exemplis, tamen, ut ipse ad meam utilitatem semper cum Graecis Latina coniunxi neque id in philosophia solum, sed etiam in dicendi exercitatione feci, idem tibi censeo faciendum, ut par sis in utriusque orationis facultate.
src_text.1: Quam quidem ad rem nos, ut videmur, magnum attulimus adiumentum hominibus nostris, ut non modo Graecarum litterarum rudes, sed etiam docti aliquantum se arbitrentur adeptos et ad dicendum et ad iudicandum.
src_text.2: Quam ob rem disces tu quidem a principe huius aetatis philosophorum, et disces, quam diu voles;
src_text.3: tam diu autem velle debebis, quoad te, quantum proficias, non paenitebit;
src_text.4: sed tamen nostra legens non multum a Peripateticis dissidentia, quoniam utrique Socratici et Platonici volumus esse, de rebus ipsis utere tuo iudicio (nihil enim impedio), orationem autem Latinam efficies profecto legendis nostris pleniorem.
src_text.5: Nec vero hoc arroganter dictum existimari velim.
src_text.6: Nam philosophandi scientiam concedens multis, quod est oratoris proprium, apte, distincte, ornate dicere, quoniam in eo studio aetatem consumpsi, si id mihi assumo, videor id meo iure quodam modo vindicare.
src_text.7: Quam ob rem magnopere te hortor, mi Cicero, ut non solum orationes meas, sed hos etiam de philosophia libros, qui iam illis fere se aequarunt, studiose legas;
src_text.8: vis enim maior in illis dicendi, sed hoc quoque colendum est aequabile et temperatum orationis genus.
src_text.9: Et id quidem nemini video Graecorum adhuc contigisse, ut idem utroque in genere elaboraret sequereturque et illud forense dicendi et hoc quietum disputandi genus, nisi forte Demetrius Phalereus in hoc numero haberi potest, disputator subtilis, orator parum vehemens, dulcis tamen, ut Theophrasti discipulum possis agnoscere.
src_text.10: Nos autem quantum in utroque profecerimus, aliorum sit iudicium, utrumque certe secuti sumus.
src_text.11: Equidem et Platonem existimo, si genus forense dicendi tractare voluisset, gravissime et copiosissime potuisse dicere, et Demosthenem, si illa, quae a Platone didicerat, tenuisset et pronuntiare voluisset, ornate splendideque facere potuisse;
src_text.12: eodemque modo de Aristotele et Isocrate iudico, quorum uterque suo studio delectatus contempsit alterum.
src_text.13: Sed cum statuissem scribere ad te aliquid hoc tempore, multa posthac, ab eo ordiri maxime volui, quod et aetati tuae esset aptissimum et auctoritati meae.
src_text.14: Nam cum multa sint in philosophia et gravia et utilia accurate copioseque a philosophis disputata, latissime patere videntur ea, quae de officiis tradita ab illis et praecepta sunt.
src_text.15: Nulla enim vitae pars neque publicis neque privatis neque forensibus neque domesticis in rebus, neque si tecum agas quid, neque si cum altero contrahas, vacare officio potest, in eoque et colendo sita vitae est honestas omnis et neglegendo turpitudo.
src_text.16: Atque haec quidem quaestio communis est omnium philosophorum;
src_text.17: quis est enim, qui nullis officii praeceptis tradendis philosophum se audeat dicere?
src_text.18: Sed sunt non nullae disciplinae, quae propositis bonorum et malorum finibus officium omne pervertant.
src_text.19: Nam qui summum bonum sic instituit, ut nihil habeat cum virtute coniunctum, idque suis commodis, non honestate metitur, hic, si sibi ipse consentiat et non interdum naturae bonitate vincatur neque amicitiam colere possit nec iustitiam nec liberalitatem;
src_text.20: fortis vero dolorem summum malum iudicans aut temperans voluptatem summum bonum statuens esse certe nullo modo potest.
src_text.21: Quae quamquam ita sunt in promptu, ut res disputatione non egeat, tamen sunt a nobis alio loco disputata.
src_text.22: Hae disciplinae igitur si sibi consentaneae velint esse, de officio nihil queant dicere, neque ulla officii praecepta firma, stabilia, coniuncta naturae tradi possunt nisi aut ab iis, qui solam, aut ab iis, qui maxime honestatem propter se dicant expetendam.
src_text.23: Ita propria est ea praeceptio Stoicorum, Academicorum, Peripateticorum, quoniam Aristonis, Pyrrhonis, Erilli iam pridem explosa sententia est;
src_text.24: qui tamen haberent ius suum disputandi de officio, si rerum aliquem dilectum reliquissent, ut ad officii inventionem aditus esset.
src_text.25: Sequemur igitur hoc quidem tempore et hac in quaestione potissimum Stoicos non ut interpretes, sed, ut solemus, e fontibus eorum iudicio arbitrioque nostro, quantum quoque modo videbitur, hauriemus.
src_text.26: Placet igitur, quoniam omnis disputatio de officio futura est, ante definire, quid sit officium;
src_text.27: quod a Panaetio praetermissum esse miror.
src_text.28: Omnis enim, quae a ratione suscipitur de aliqua re institutio, debet a definitione proficisci, ut intellegatur, quid sit id, de quo disputetur  Omnis de officio duplex est quaestio:

src_text.30: Superioris generis huius modi sunt exempla:
src_text.31: omniane officia perfecta sint, num quod officium aliud alio maius sit, et quae sunt generis eiusdem.
src_text.32: Quorum autem officiorum praecepta traduntur, ea quamquam pertinent ad finem bonorum, tamen minus id apparet, quia magis ad institutionem vitae communis spectare videntur;

src_text.34: Atque etiam alia divisio est officii.
src_text.35: Nam et medium quoddam officium dicitur et perfectum.

src_text.37: Atque ea sic definiunt, ut, rectum quod sit, id officium perfectum esse definiant;
src_text.38: medium autem officium id esse dicunt, quod cur factum sit, ratio probabilis reddi possit.
src_text.39: Triplex igitur est, ut Panaetio videtur, consilii capiendi deliberatio.
src_text.40: Nam aut honestumne factu sit an turpe dubitant id, quod in deliberationem cadit;
src_text.41: in quo considerando saepe animi in contraries sententias distrahuntur.
src_text.42: Tum autem aut anquirunt aut consultant, ad vitae commoditatem iucunditatemque, ad facultates rerum atque copias, ad opes, ad potentiam, quibus et se possint iuvare et suos, conducat id necne, de quo deliberant;
src_text.43: quae deliberatio omnis in rationem utilitatis cadit.
src_text.44: Tertium dubitandi genus est, cum pugnare videtur cum honesto id, quod videtur esse utile;
src_text.45: cum enim utilitas ad se rapere, honestas contra revocare ad se videtur, fit ut distrahatur in deliberando animus afferatque ancipitem curam cogitandi.
src_text.46: Hac divisione, cum praeterire aliquid maximum vitium in dividendo sit, duo praetermissa sunt;
src_text.47: nec enim solum utrum honestum an turpe sit, deliberari solet, sed etiam duobus propositis honestis utrum honestius, itemque duobus propositis utilibus utrum utilius.
src_text.48: Ita, quam ille triplicem putavit esse rationem, in quinque partes distribui debere reperitur.
src_text.49: Primum igitur est de honesto, sed dupliciter, tum pari ratione de utili, post de comparatione eorum disserendum.
src_text.50: Principio generi animantium omni est a natura tributum, ut se, vitam corpusque tueatur, declinet ea, quae nocitura videantur, omniaque, quae sint ad vivendum necessaria, anquirat et paret, ut pastum, ut latibula, ut alia generis eiusdem.
src_text.51: Commune item animantium omnium est coniunctionis adpetitus procreandi causa et cura quaedam eorum, quae procreata sint;
src_text.52: sed inter hominem et beluam hoc maxime interest, quod haec tantum, quantum sensu movetur, ad id solum, quod adest quodque praesens est, se accommodat paulum admodum sentiens praeteritum aut futurum;
src_text.53: homo autem, quod rationis est particeps, per quam consequentia cernit, causas rerum videt earumque praegressus et quasi antecessiones non ignorat, similitudines comparat rebusque praesentibus adiungit atque annectit futuras, facile totius vitae cursum videt ad eamque degendam praeparat res necessarias.
src_text.54: Eademque natura vi rationis hominem conciliat homini et ad orationis et ad vitae societatem ingeneratque in primis praecipuum quendam amorem in eos, qui procreati sunt, impellitque, ut hominum coetus et celebrationes et esse et a se obiri velit ob easque causas studeat parare ea, quae suppeditent ad cultum et ad victum, nec sibi soli, sed coniugi, liberis ceterisque, quos caros habeat tuerique debeat;
src_text.55: quae cura exsuscitat etiam animos et maiores ad rem gerendam facit.
src_text.56: In primisque hominis est propria veri inquisitio atque investigatio.
src_text.57: Itaque cum sumus necessariis negotiis curisque vacui, tum avemus aliquid videre, audire, addiscere cognitionemque rerum aut occultarum aut admirabilium ad beate vivendum necessariam ducimus.
src_text.58: Ex quo intellegitur, quod verum, simplex sincerumque sit, id esse naturae hominis aptissimum.
src_text.59: Huic veri videndi cupiditati adiuncta est appetitio quaedam principatus, ut nemini parere animus bene informatus a natura velit nisi praecipienti aut docenti aut utilitatis causa iuste et legitime imperanti;
src_text.60: ex quo magnitudo animi exsistit humanarumque rerum contemptio.
src_text.61: Nec vero illa parva vis naturae est rationisque.
src_text.62: quod unum hoc animal sentit, quid sit ordo, quid sit, quod deceat, in factis dictisque qui modus.
src_text.63: Itaque eorum ipsorum, quae aspectu sentiuntur, nullum aliud animal pulchritudinem, venustatem, convenientiam partium sentit;

src_text.65: Quibus ex rebus conflatur et efficitur id, quod quaerimus, honestum, quod etiamsi nobilitatum non sit, tamen honestum sit, quodque vere dicimus, etiamsi a nullo laudetur, natura esse laudabile.
src_text.66: Formam quidem ipsam, Marce fili, et tamquam faciem honesti vides, quae si oculis cerneretur, mirabiles amores, ut ait Plato, excitaret sapientiae.
src_text.67: Sed omne, quod est honestum, id quattuor partium oritur ex aliqua:
src_text.68: aut enim in perspicientia veri sollertiaque versatur aut in hominum societate tuenda tribuendoque suum cuique et rerum contractarum fide aut in animi excelsi atque invicti magnitudine ac robore aut in omnium, quae fiunt quaeque dicuntur, ordine et modo, in quo inest modestia et temperantia.
src_text.69: Quae quattuor quamquam inter se colligata atque implicata sunt, tamen ex singulis certa officiorum genera nascuntur, velut ex ea parte, quae prima discripta est, in qua sapientiam et prudentiam ponimus, inest indagatio atque inventio veri, eiusque virtutis hoc munus est proprium.
src_text.70: Ut enim quisque maxime perspicit, quid in re quaque verissimum sit.
src_text.71: quique acutissime et celerrime potest et videre et explicare rationem, is prudentissimus et sapientissimus rite haberi solet.
src_text.72: Quocirca huic quasi materia, quam tractet et in qua versetur, subiecta est veritas.
src_text.73: Reliquis autem tribus virtutibus necessitates propositae sunt ad eas res parandas tuendasque, quibus actio vitae continetur, ut et societas hominum coniunctioque servetur et animi excellentia magnitudoque cum in augendis opibus utilitatibusque et sibi et suis comparandis, tum multo magis in his ipsis despiciendis eluceat.
src_text.74: Ordo autem et constantia et moderatio et ea, quae sunt his similia, versantur in eo genere, ad quod est adhibenda actio quaedam, non solum mentis agitatio.

src_text.76: Ex quattuor autem locis, in quos honesti naturam vimque divisimus, primus ille, qui in veri cognitione consistit, maxime naturam attingit humanam.
src_text.77: Omnes enim trahimur et ducimur ad cognitionis et scientiae cupiditatem, in qua excellere pulchrum putamus, labi autem, errare, nescire, decipi et malum et turpe ducimus.

src_text.79: quod vitium effugere qui volet (omnes autem velle debent), adhibebit ad considerandas res et tempus et diligentiam.
src_text.80: Alterum est vitium, quod quidam nimis magnum studium multamque operam in res obscuras atque difficiles conferunt easdemque non necessarias.

src_text.88: Ac de primo quidem officii fonte diximus.

src_text.96: e quo si quis sibi appetet, violabit ius humanae societatis.
src_text.97: Sed quoniam, ut praeclare scriptum est a Platone, non nobis solum nati sumus ortusque nostri partem patria vindicat, partem amici, atque, ut placet Stoicis, quae in terris gignantur, ad usum hominum omnia creari, homines autem hominum causa esse generatos, ut ipsi inter se aliis alii prodesse possent, in hoc naturam debemus ducem sequi, communes utilitates in medium afferre mutatione officiorum, dando accipiendo, tum artibus, tum opera, tum facultatibus devincire hominum inter homines societatem.
src_text.98: Fundamentum autem est iustitiae fides, id est dictorum conventorumque constantia et veritas.
src_text.99: Ex quo, quamquam hoc videbitur fortasse cuipiam durius, tamen audeamus imitari Stoicos, qui studiose exquirunt, unde verba sint ducta, credamusque, quia fiat, quod dictum est, appellatam fidem.
src_text.100: Sed iniustitiae genera duo sunt, unum eorum, qui inferunt, alterum eorum, qui ab iis, quibus infertur, si possunt, non propulsant iniuriam.
src_text.101: Nam qui iniuste impetum in quempiam facit aut ira aut aliqua perturbatione incitatus, is quasi manus afferre videtur socio;

src_text.508: Quo genere non modo Plautus noster et Atticorum antiqua comoedia, sed etiam philosophorum Socraticorum libri referti sunt, multaque multorum facete dicta, ut ea, quae a sene Catone collecta sunt, quae vocant a)pofqe/gmata.
src_text.509: Facilis igitur est distinctio ingenui et illiberalis ioci.
src_text.510: Alter est, si tempore fit, ut si remisso animo, gravissimo homine dignus, alter ne libero quidem, si rerum turpitudini adhibetur verborum obscenitas.
src_text.511: Ludendi etiam est quidam modus retinendus, ut ne nimis omnia profundamus elatique voluptate in aliquam turpitudinem delabamur.
src_text.512: Suppeditant autem et campus noster et studia venandi honesta exempla ludendi.
src_text.513: Sed pertinet ad omnem officii quaestionem semper in promptu habere, quantum natura hominis pecudibus reliquisque beluis antecedat;

src_text.515: Quin etiam, si quis est paulo ad voluptates propensior, modo ne sit ex pecudum genere (sunt enim quidam homines non re, sed nomine), sed si quis est paulo erectior, quamvis voluptate capiatur, occultat et dissimulat appetitum voluptatis propter verecundiam.
src_text.516: Ex quo intellegitur corporis voluptatem non satis esse dignam hominis praestantia, eamque contemni et reici oportere;

src_text.518: Itaque victus cultusque corporis ad valetudinem referatur et ad vires, non ad voluptatem.
src_text.519: Atque etiam si considerare volumus, quae sit in natura excellentia et dignitas, intellegemus, quam sit turpe diffluere luxuria et delicate ac molliter vivere quamque honestum parce, continenter, severe, sobrie.

src_text.522: Ut enim in corporibus magnae dissimilitudines sunt (alios videmus velocitate ad cursum, alios viribus ad luctandum valere, itemque in formis aliis dignitatem inesse, aliis venustatem), sic in animis exsistunt maiores etiam varietates.

src_text.540: Ex quo magis emergit, quale sit decorum illud, ideo quia nihil decet invita Minerva, ut aiunt, id est adversante et repugnante natura.

src_text.542: Ut enim sermone eo debemus uti, qui innatus est nobis, ne, ut quidam, Graeca verba inculcantes iure optimo rideamur, sic in actiones omnemque vitam nullam discrepantiam conferre debemus.

src_text.562: Itaque se alii ad philosophiam, alii ad ius civile, alii ad eloquentiam applicant, ipsarumque virtutum in alia alius mavult excellere.
src_text.563: Quorum vero patres aut maiores aliqua gloria praestiterunt, ii student plerumque eodem in genere laudis excellere, ut Q. Mucius P. f. in iure civili, Pauli filius Africanus in re militari.

src_text.566: Fit autem interdum, ut non nulli omissa imitatione maiorum suum quoddam institutum consequantur, maximeque in eo plerumque elaborant ii, qui magna sibi proponunt obscuris orti maioribus.
src_text.567: Haec igitur omnia, cum quaerimus, quid deceat, complecti animo et cogitatione debemus;

src_text.571: Nam quodHerculem Prodicus dicit, ut est apud Xenophontem, cum primum pubesceret, quod tempus a natura ad deligendum, quam quisque viam vivendi sit ingressurus, datum est, exisse in solitudinem atque ibi sedentem diu secum multumque dubitasse, cum duas cerneret vias, unam Voluptatis, alteram Virtutis, utram ingredi melius esset, hoc Herculi Iovis satu edito potuit fortasse contingere, nobis non item, qui imitamur, quos cuique visum est, atque ad eorum studia institutaque impellimur;
src_text.572: plerumque autem parentium praeceptis imbuti ad eorum consuetudinem moremque deducimur;

src_text.575: Illud autem maxime rarum genus est eorum, qui aut excellenti ingenii magnitudine aut praeclara eruditione atque doctrina aut utraque re ornati spatium etiam deliberandi habuerunt, quem potissimum vitae cursum sequi vellent;

src_text.577: Nam cum in omnibus, quae aguntur, ex eo, quo modo quisque natus est, ut supra dictum est, quid deceat, exquirimus, tum in tota vita constituenda multo est ei rei cura maior adhibenda, ut constare in perpetuitate vitae possimus nobismet ipsis nec in ullo officio claudicare.
src_text.578: Ad hanc autem rationem quoniam maximam vim natura habet, fortuna proximam, utriusque omnino habenda ratio est in deligendo genere vitae, sed naturae magis;

src_text.580: Qui igitur ad naturae suae non vitiosae genus consilium vivendi omne contulerit, is constantiam teneat (id enim maxime decet), nisi forte se intellexerit errasse in deligendo genere vitae.
src_text.581: Quod si acciderit (potest autem accidere), facienda morum institutorumque mutatio est.

src_text.585: Sed quoniam paulo ante dictum est imitandos esse maiores, primum illud exceptum sit, ne vitia sint imitanda, deinde si natura non feret, ut quaedam imitari posit (ut superioris filius Africani, qui hunc Paulo natum adoptavit, propter infirmitatem valetudinis non tam potuit patris similis esse, quam ille fuerat sui);

src_text.590: ineuntis enim aetatis inscitia senum constituenda et regenda prudentia est.
src_text.591: Maxime autem haec aetas a libidinibus arcenda est exercendaque in labore patientiaque et animi et corporis, ut eorum et in bellicis et in civilibus officiis vigeat industria.

src_text.605: Sed quoniam decorum il!id in omnibus factis, dictis, in corporis denique motu et statu cernitur idque positum est in tribus rebus, formositate, ordine, ornatu ad actionem apto, difficilibus ad eloquendum, sed satis erit intellegi, in his autem tribus continetur cura etiam illa, ut probemur iis, quibuscum apud quosque vivamus, his quoque de rebus pauca dicantur.

src_text.832: Quorum error eripiendus est opinioque omnis ad eam spem traducenda, ut honestis consiliis iustisque factis, non fraude et malitia se intellegant ea, quae velint, consequi posse.
src_text.833: Quae ergo ad vitam hominum tuendam pertinent, partim sunt inanima, ut aurum, argentum, ut ea, quae gignuntur e terra, ut alia generis eiusdem, partim animalia, quae habent suos impetus et rerum appetitus.
src_text.834: Eorum autem alia rationis expertia sunt, alia ratione utentia;

src_text.836: ratione autem utentium duo genera ponunt, deorum unum, alterum hominum.
src_text.837: Deos placatos pietas efficiet et sanctitas, proxime autem et secundum deos homines hominibus maxime utiles esse possunt.
src_text.838: Earumque item rerum, quae noceant et obsint, eadem divisio est.
src_text.839: Sed quia deos nocere non putant, iis exceptis homines hominibus obesse plurimum arbitrantur.
src_text.840: Ea enim ipsa, quae inanima diximus, pleraque sunt hominum operis effecta;

src_text.842: Neque enim valetudinis curatio neque navigatio neque agri cultura neque frugum fructuumque reliquorum perceptio et conservatio sine hominum opera ulla esse potuisset.
src_text.843: Iam vero et earum rerum, quibus abundaremus, exportatio et earum, quibus egeremus, invectio certe nulla esset, nisi his muneribus homines fungerentur.
src_text.844: Eademque ratione nec lapides ex terra exciderentur ad usum nostrum necessarii, nec ferrum, aes, aurum, argentum effoderetur penitus abditum sine hominum labore et manu.
src_text.845: Tecta vero, quibus et frigorum vis pelleretur et calorum molestiae sedarentur, unde aut initio generi humano dari potuissent aut postea subveniri, si aut vi tempestatis aut terrae motu aut vetustate cecidissent, nisi communis vita ab hominibus harum rerum auxilia petere didicisset?
src_text.846: Adde ductus aquarum, derivationes fluminum, agrorum irrigationes, moles oppositas fluctibus, portus manu factos, quae unde sine hominum opere habere possemus?
src_text.847: Ex quibus multisque aliis perspicuum est, qui fructus quaeque utilitates ex rebus iis,quae sint inanimae,percipiantur,eas nosnullo modo sine hominum manu atque opera capere potuisse.
src_text.848: Qui denique ex bestiis fructus aut quae commoditas, nisi homines adiuvarent, percipi posset?
src_text.849: Nam et qui principes inveniendi fuerunt, quem ex quaque belua usum habere possemus, homines certe fuerunt, nec hoc tempore sine hominum opera aut pascere eas aut domare aut tueri aut tempestivos fructus ex iis capere possemus;
src_text.850: ab eisdemque et, quae nocent, interficiuntur et, quae usui possunt esse, capiuntur.
src_text.851: Quid enumerem artium multitudinem, sine quibus vita omnino nulla esse potuisset?

src_text.853: quibus rebus exculta hominum vita tantum distat a victu et cultu bestiarum.
src_text.854: Urbes vero sine hominum coetu non potuissent nec aedificari nec frequentari;
src_text.855: ex quo leges moresque constituti, tum iuris aequa discriptio certaque vivendi disciplina;
src_text.856: quas res et mansuetudo animorum consecuta et verecundia est effectumque, ut esset vita munitior, atque ut dando et accipiendo mutuandisque facultatibus et commodandis nulla re egeremus.
src_text.857: Longiores hoc loco sumus, quam necesse est.
src_text.858: Quis est enim, cui non perspicua sint illa, quae pluribus verbis a Panaetio commemorantur, neminem neque ducem bello nec principem domi magnas res et salutares sine hominum studiis gerere potuisse?
src_text.859: Commemoratur ab eo Themistocles, Pericles, Cyrus, Agesilaus, Alexander, quos negat sine adiumentis hominum tantas res efficere potuisse.
src_text.860: Utitur in re non dubia testibus non necessariis.
src_text.861: Atque ut magnas utilitates adipiscimur conspiratione hominum atque consensu, sic nulla tam detestabilis pestis est, quae non homini ab homine nascatur.
src_text.862: Est Dicaearchi liber de interitu hominum, Peripatetici magni et copiosi, qui collectis ceteris causis eluvionis, pestilentiae, vastitatis, beluarum etiam repentinae multitudinis, quarum impetu docet quaedam hominum genera esse consumpta, deinde comparat, quanto plures deleti sint homines hominum impetu, id est bellis aut seditionibus, quam omni reliqua calamitate.
src_text.863: Cum igitur hie locus nihil habeat dubitationis, quin homines plurimum hominibus et prosint et obsint, proprium hoc statuo esse virtutis, conciliare animos hominum et ad usus suos adiungere.
src_text.864: Itaque, quae in rebus inanimis quaeque in usu et tractatione beluarum fiunt utiliter ad hominum vitam, artibus ea tribuuntur operosis, hominum autem studia ad amplificationem nostrarum rerum prompta ac parata virorum praestantium sapientia et virtute excitantur.
src_text.865: Etenim virtus omnis tribus in rebus fere vertitur, quarum una est in perspiciendo, quid in quaque re verum sincerumque sit, quid consentaneum cuique, quid consequens, ex quo quaeque gignantur, quae cuiusque rei causa sit, alterum cohibere motus animi turbatos, quos Graeci pa/qh nominant, appetitionesque, quas illi o(rma/s, oboedientes efficere rationi, tertium iis, quibuscum congregemur, uti moderate et scienter, quorum studiis ea, quae natura desiderat, expleta cumulataque habeamus, per eosdemque, si quid importetur nobis incommodi, propulsemus ulciscamurque eos, qui nocere nobis conati sint, tantaque poena afficiamus, quantam aequitas humanitasque patitur.
src_text.866: Quibus autem rationibus hanc facultatem assequi possimus, ut hominum studia complectamur eaque teneamus, dicemus, neque ita multo post, sed pauca ante dicenda sunt.
src_text.867: Magnam vim esse in fortuna in utramque partem, vel secundas ad res vel adversas, quis ignorat?
src_text.868: Nam et, cum prospero flatu eius utimur, ad exitus pervehimur optatos et, cum reflavit, affligimur.
src_text.869: Haec igitur ipsa fortuna ceteros casus rariores habet, primum ab inanimis procellas, tempestates, naufragia, ruinas, incendia, deinde a bestiis ictus, morsus, impetus;
src_text.871: At vero interitus exercituum, ut proxime trium, saepe multorum, clades imperatorum, ut nuper summi et singularis viri, invidiae praeterea multitudinis atque ob eas bene meritorum saepe civium expulsiones, calamitates, fugae, rursusque secundae res, honores, imperia, victoriae, quamquam fortuita sunt, tamen sine hominum opibus et studiis neutram in partem effici possunt.
src_text.872: Hoc igitur cognito dicendum est, quonam modo hominum studia ad utilitates nostras allicere atque excitare possimus.
src_text.873: Quae si longior fuerit oratio, cum magnitudine utilitatis comparetur;
src_text.875: Quaecumque igitur homines homini tribuunt ad eum augendum atque honestandum, aut benivolentiae gratia faciunt, cum aliqua de causa quempiam diligunt, aut honoris, si cuius virtutem suspiciunt, quemque dignum fortuna quam amplissima putant, aut cui fidem habent et bene rebus suis consulere arbitrantur, aut cuius opes metuunt, aut contra, a quibus aliquid exspectant, ut cum reges popularesve homines largitiones aliquas proponunt, aut postremo pretio ac mercede ducuntur, quae sordidissima, est illa quidem ratio et inquinatissima et iis, qui ea tenentur, et illis, qui ad eam confugere conantur;

src_text.877: Sed quoniam non numquam hoc subsidium necessarium est, quem ad modum sit utendum eo, dicemus, si prius iis de rebus, quae virtuti propiores sunt, dixerimus.
src_text.878: Atque etiam subiciunt se homines imperio alterius et potestati de causis pluribus.

src_text.880: Omnium autem rerum nec aptius est quicquam ad opes tuendas ac tenendas quam diligi nec alienius quam timeri.

src_text.897: O miserum, qui fideliorem et barbarum et stigmatiam putaret quam coniugem! Nec eum fefellit;

src_text.912: Secutus est, qui in causa impia, victoria etiam foediore non singulorum civium bona publicaret, sed universas provincias regionesque uno calamitatis iure comprehenderet.

src_text.914: Multa praeterea commemorarem nefaria in socios, si hoc uno quicquam sol vidisset indignius, lure igitur plectimur.

src_text.919: alter autem, qui in illa dictatura scriba fuerat, in hac fuit quaestor urbanus.

src_text.922: Atque in has clades incidimus (redeundum est enim ad propositum), dum metui quam carl esse et diligi malumus.

src_text.925: Sed ea non pariter omnes egemus;

src_text.927: Certum igitur hoc sit, idque et primum et maxime necessarium, familiaritates habere fidas amantium nos amicorum et nostra mirantium;

src_text.929: Honore et gloria et benivolentia civium fortasse non aeque omnes egent, sed tamen, si cui haec suppetunt, adiuvant aliquantum cum ad cetera, tum ad amicitias comparandas.

src_text.935: Sed est alius quoque quidam aditus ad multitudinem, ut in universorum animos tamquam influere possimus.
src_text.936: Ac primum de illis tribus, quae ante dixi, benivolentiae praecepta videamus;

src_text.939: Etenim illud ipsum, quod honestum decorumque dicimus, quia per se nobis placet animosque omnium natura et specie sua commovet maximeque quasi perlucet ex iis, quas commemoravi, virtutibus, idcirco illos, in quibus eas virtutes esse remur, a natura ipsa diligere cogimur.
src_text.940: Atque hae quidem causae diligendi gravissimae;

src_text.942: Fides autem ut habeatur, duabus rebus effici potest, si existimabimur adepti coniunctam cum iustitia prudentiam.
src_text.943: Nam et iis fidem habemus, quos plus intellegere quam nos arbitramur quosque et futura prospicere credimus et, cum res agatur in discrimenque ventum sit, expedire rem et consilium ex tempore capere posse;
src_text.944: hanc enim utilem homines existimant veramque prudentiam.
src_text.945: Iustis autem et fidis hominibus, id est bonis viris, ita fides habetur, ut nulla sit in iis fraudis iniuriaeque suspicio.

src_text.947: Harum igitur duarum ad fidem faciendam iustitia plus pollet, quippe cum ea sine prudentia satis habeat auctoritatis, prudentia sine iustitia nihil valet ad faciendam fidem.
src_text.948: Quo enim quis versutior et callidior, hoc invisior et suspectior est detracta opinione probitatis.
src_text.949: Quam ob rem intellegentiae iustitia coniuncta, quantum volet, habebit ad faciendam fidem virium;

src_text.951: Sed ne quis sit admiratus, cur, cum inter omnes philosophos constet a meque ipso saepe disputatum sit, qui unam haberet, omnes habere virtutes, nune ita seiungam, quasi possit quisquam, qui non idem prudens sit, iustus esse, alia est illa, cum veritas ipsa limatur in disputatione, subtilitas, alia, cum ad opinionem communem omnis accommodatur oratio.
src_text.952: Quam ob rem, ut volgus, ita nos hoc loco loquimur, ut alios fortes, alios viros bonos, alios prudentes esse dicamus;

src_text.955: Erat igitur ex iis tribus, quae ad gloriam pertinerent, hoc tertium, ut cum admiratione hominum honore ab iis digni iudicaremur.
src_text.956: Admirantur igitur communiter illi quidem omnia, quae magna et praeter opinionem suam animadverterunt, separatim autem, in singulis si perspiciunt necopinata quaedam bona.
src_text.957: Itaque eos viros suspiciunt maximisque efferunt laudibus, in quibus existimant se excellentes quasdam et singulares perspicere virtutes, despiciunt autem eos et contemnunt, in quibus nihil virtutis, nihil animi, nihil nervorum putant.
src_text.958: Non enim omnes eos contemnunt, de quibus male existimant.
src_text.959: Nam quos improbos, maledicos, fraudulentos putant et ad faciendam iniuriam instructos, eos haud contemnunt quidem, sed de iis male existimant.
src_text.960: Quam ob rem, ut ante dixi, contemnuntur ii, qui nec sibi nec alteri, ut dicitur, in quibus nullus labor, nulla industria, nulla cura est.
src_text.961: Admiratione autem afficiuntur ii, qui anteire ceteris virtute putantur et cum omni carere dedecore, tum vero iis vitiis, quibus alii non facile possunt obsistere.

src_text.966: Ergo et haec animi despicientia admirabilitatem magnam facit et maxime iustitia, ex qua una virtute viri boni appellantur, mirifica quaedam multitudini videtur, nec iniuria;

src_text.968: Maximeque admirantur eum, qui pecunia non movetur;

tgt_text.172: But what is deplorable in this matter is, that the desire after honour, empire, power, and glory, is generally most prevalent in the greatest soul and the most exalted genius ;
tgt_text.173: * for which reason every crime of that sort is the more carefully to be guarded against.
tgt_text.174: But in every species of injustice it is a very material question, whether it is committed through some agitation of passion, which commonly is short-lived and tem- porary, or from deliberate, prepense, malice;
tgt_text.175: for those things which proceed from a short, sudden fit, are of slighter moment than those which are inflicted by forethought and prepara- tion.
tgt_text.176: But enough has been said concerning inflicting injury.
tgt_text.178: Various are the causes of men omitting the defence of others, or neglecting their duty towards them.
tgt_text.179: They are either unwilling to encounter enmity, toil, or expense ;
tgt_text.180: or, perhaps, they do it through negligence, listlessness, or lazi- ness ;
tgt_text.181: or they are so embarrassed in certain studies and pursuits, that they suffer those they ought to protect to be neglected.
tgt_text.182: Hence we must take care lest Plato's observa- tion with respect to philosophers should be falsified :
tgt_text.184: That they are men of integrity, because they are solely engaged in the pursuit of truth, and despise and neglect those con- siderations which others value, and which mankind are wont to contend for amongst themselves."
tgt_text.185: For, while they abstain from hurting any by the infliction of injury, they indeed assert one species of honesty or justice, but they fail in another;
tgt_text.186: because, being entangled in the pursuits of learn- in-, they abandon those they ought to protect.
tgt_text.187: Some, therefore, think that they would have no concern with the government unless they were forced to it;
tgt_text.188: but still, it would be more just that it should be done voluntarily;
tgt_text.189: for an action which is intrinsically right is only morally good in so far as it is voluntary.*
tgt_text.190: There are others who, either from a desire to improve their private fortune, or from some per- sonal resentments, pretend that they mind their own affairs only that they may'appear not to do wrong to another.
tgt_text.191: Now such persons are free from one kind of injustice, but fall into another ;
tgt_text.192: because they abandon the fellowship of life by employing in it none of their zeal, none of their labour, none of their abilities.
tgt_text.193: Having thus stated the two kinds of dis- honesty or injustice, and assigned the motives for each kind, and settled previously the considerations by which justice is limited, we shall easily (unless we are extremely selfish) be able to form a judgment of our duty on every occasion.
tgt_text.194: For, to concern ourselves in other people's affairs is a delicate matter.
tgt_text.195: Yet Chremes, a character in Terence, thinks, that there is nothing which has a relation to mankind in which he has not a concern.†
tgt_text.196: Meanwhile, because we have the quicker perception and sensation of whatever happens favourably or untowardly to ourselves than to others, which we see as it were at a greater distance, the judgment we form of them is very different from what we form of ourselves.
tgt_text.197: Those therefore are wise monitors who teach us to do nothing of which we are doubtful, whether it is honest or unjust ;
tgt_text.198: for whatever is honest manifests itself by its own lustre, but doubt implies the entertainment of injustice.
tgt_text.200: But occasions frequently happen in which those duties which are most worthy of an honest, and of such as we call a worthy man, are altered and changed to their contraries.
tgt_text.201: For example, to return a deposit, to perform a promise, and other matters that are relative to truth and honesty, some- times alter so, that it is just they should not be observed ;
tgt_text.202: for it is proper to have recourse to those fundamentals of honesty which I laid down in the commencement:
tgt_text.203: in the first place, that of injuring no person ;
tgt_text.204: and, secondly, that of being sub- servient to the public good.
tgt_text.205: When these conditions are altered by circumstances, the moral obligation, not being in- variably identical, is similarly altered.
tgt_text.206: A promise, as a paction, may happen to be made, the performance of which may be prejudicial either to the party promising, or to the party to whom the promise is made.
tgt_text.207: For (as we see in the play) had not Neptune performed his promise to Theseus, the latter would not have been bereaved of his son, Hippolytus ;
tgt_text.208: for it is recorded, that of three wishes to be granted him, the third, which he made in a passion, was the death of Hippolytus, which, having been granted, he sunk into the most dreadful distress.
tgt_text.209: Therefore, you are not to perform those promises which may be prejudicial to the party to whom you promise, nor if they may be more hurtful to you than they can be serviceable to him.
tgt_text.210: It is inconsistent with our duty that the greater obligation should be postponed to the less.
tgt_text.211: For instance, suppose you should promise to appear as the advocate of another person while his cause is depending:
tgt_text.212: now, if your son was to be seized violently ill in the meantime, it would be no breach of duty in you not to perform what you promise ;
tgt_text.213: the other person would rather depart from his duty if he should complain that he had been abandoned.
tgt_text.214: Who, then, does not see that a man is not bound by those promises which he makes either when coerced by fear,* or seduced by deceit ?
tgt_text.215: Many such promises are cancelled by the edict of the prætor's court, some by the laws;
tgt_text.216: for very often wrongs arise through a quirk, and through a too artful but fraudulent construction of the law.
tgt_text.217: Hence, " the rigour of law is the rigour of injustice," is a saying that has now passed into a proverb.
tgt_text.218: Many injuries of this kind happen even in state affairs:
tgt_text.219: thus, when a general had con- cluded a truce with his enemy for thirty days, yet ravaged that enemy's territories every night, because the truce was only for so many days, not for the nights.
tgt_text.220: Nor, indeed, if it is true, is the conduct of our countryman, Quintus Fabius Labeo, to be approved of, or whoever he was (for I have the story only by report), who, being appointed an arbiter by the senate to settle a boundary between the people of Nola and those of Naples, counselled each of those people separately to do nothing covetously, and that each ought rather to draw back than advance.
tgt_text.221: Both of them taking this advice, a space of unoccupied ground was left in the middle.
tgt_text.222: He, therefore, adjudged to each people the boundary to which they had confined themselves, and all that was in the middle to the people of Rome.
tgt_text.223: This was not to give judgment but to cheat;
tgt_text.224: wherefore we ought to avoid all chicane of that kind in every transaction.
tgt_text.225: †XI. Certain duties are also to be observed, even towards those who have wronged you;
tgt_text.226: for there is a mean even in revenge and punishments.
tgt_text.227: Nay, I am not certain whether it is not sufficient for the person who has injured you to repent of the wrong done, so that he may never be guilty of the like in future, and that others may not be so forward to offend in the same manner.*
tgt_text.228: Now, in government the laws of war are to be most especially observed;
tgt_text.229: for since there are two manners of disputing, one by debating, the other by fighting, though the former characterises men, the latter, brutes, if the former cannot be adopted, recourse must be had to the latter.
tgt_text.230: Wars, therefore, are to be undertaken for this end, that we may live in peace without being injured;
tgt_text.231: but when we obtain the victory, we must preserve those enemies who behaved without cruelty or inhumanity during the war:
tgt_text.232: for example, our forefathers received, even as members of their state, the Tuscans, the .AEqui, the Volscians, the Sabines, and the Hernici, but utterly destroyed Carthage and Nu- mantia.
tgt_text.233: I am unwilling to mention Corinth;
tgt_text.234: but I believe they had some object in it, and particularly they were induced to destroy it, lest the advantages of its situation should invite the inhabitants to make war in future times.
tgt_text.235: In my opinion, we ought always to consult for peace, which should have in it nothing of perfidy.
tgt_text.236: Had my voice been followed on this head, we might still have had some form of government (if not the best), whereas now we have none.
tgt_text.237: And, while we are bound to exercise consideration toward those whom we have conquered by force, so those should be received into our protection who throw themselves upon the honour of our general, and lay down their arms, even though the battering rams should have struck their walls.
tgt_text.238: In which matter justice was cultivated with so much care among our countrymen, that it was a custom among our ancestors that they who received under their protection cities, or nations conquered in war, became their patrons.
tgt_text.239: Now, the justice of war was most religiously pointed out by the fecial law of the Romans.
tgt_text.240: From this it may be understood that no war is just unless it is undertaken to reclaim property,* or unless it is solemnly denounced and proclaimed beforehand.
tgt_text.241: Popilius, as general, held a province where Cato's son served in his army.
tgt_text.242: It happened that Popilius thought proper to disband one legion ;
tgt_text.243: he dismissed, at the same time, Cato's son, who was serving in that legion.
tgt_text.244: When, however, through love of a military life, he remained in the army, his father wrote to Popilius, that if he suffered him to continue in the service he should, for a second time bind him by the military oath ;
tgt_text.245: because the obligation of the former having been annulled, he could not lawfully fight with the enemy.
tgt_text.246: So very strict was their observance of laws in making war.
tgt_text.247: There is extant a letter of old Cato to his soil on this occasion, in which he writes, " That he heard he had got his discharge from the consul, while he was serving as a soldier in Macedonia, during the war with Perseus.
tgt_text.248: He, therefore, enjoins him to take care not to enter upon action ;
tgt_text.249: for he declares that it is not lawful for a man who is not a soldier to fight with an enemy.
tgt_text.251: And, indeed, there is another thing that I should observe, that he who ought properly be termed perduellis, that is, a stubborn foe, is called a hostis, and thereby the softness of the appellation lessens the horror of the thing ;
tgt_text.252: for by our ancestors he was called hostis whom we now call a stranger.
tgt_text.254: as in the words, "a day appointed for the hostis to plead;
tgt_text.255: " and again, "a Roman's right of property, as against a hostis, never terminates."
tgt_text.256: What can exceed the gentleness of this, to call those with whom you were at war by so soft an appellation ?
tgt_text.257: It is true that length of time has affixed a harsher significa- tion to this word, which has now ceased to be applied to the stranger, and remains peculiar to him who carries arms against us.
tgt_text.258: Meanwhile, when we fight for empire, and when we seek glory in arms, all those grounds of war which I have already enumerated to be just ones, must absolutely be in force.
tgt_text.259: But wars that are founded upon the glory of con- quest alone, are to be carried on with less rancour;
tgt_text.260: for, as we treat a fellow citizen in a different manner as a foe, than we do as an antagonist;
tgt_text.261: -as with the latter the struggle is for glory and power, as the former for life and reputation;
tgt_text.262: - thus we fought against the Celtiberians and the Cimbrians as against enemies, the question being not who should com- mand but who should exist;
tgt_text.263: but we fought for empire against the Latines, the Sabines, the Samnites, the Cartha- ginians, and Pyrrhus.
tgt_text.264: The Carthaginians, 'tis true, were faithless, and Hannibal was cruel, but the others were better principled.
tgt_text.265: The speech of Pyrrhus about ransoming the captives is a noble one:
tgt_text.266: -In war not crafty, but in battle bold, No wealth I value, and I spurn at gold.
tgt_text.267: Be steel the only metal shall decree
tgt_text.268: The fate of empire, or to you or me.
tgt_text.269: The gen'rous conquest be by courage tried, And all the captives on the Roman side, I swear, by all the gods of open war, As fate their lives, their freedom I will spare.
tgt_text.270: This sentiment is truly noble, and worthy the descendant of the Æacidæ.
tgt_text.272: Nay, if even private persons should, induced by circumstances, make a promise to the enemy, even in this fidelity should be observed.
tgt_text.273: Thus Regulus, when be was made a prisoner by the Carthaginians in the first Punic war, being sent to Rome to treat of an exchange of prisoners, he swore that he would return.
tgt_text.274: The first thing he did when he came to Rome was to deliver his opinion in the senate that the prisoners should not be restored;
tgt_text.275: and after that, when he was detained by his relations and friends, he chose to deliver himself up to a cruel death rather than to falsify his word to the enemy.
tgt_text.276: But in the second Punic war, after the battle of Cannæ, Hannibal sent ten Romans to Rome, under an oath that they would return to him unless they procured the prisoners to be ransomed ;
tgt_text.277: but the censors disfranchised, as long as they lived, all of them that were perjured, as well as him who had devised a fraudulent evasion of his oath.
tgt_text.278: For when, by the leave of Hannibal, he had left the camp, he returned soon after, to say that he had forgotten something;
tgt_text.279: and then again leaving the camp he considered himself free from the obligations of his oath, which he was with regard to the words but not the meaning of them;
tgt_text.280: for in a promise, what you thought, and not what you said, is always to be consi- dered.*
tgt_text.281: But our forefathers set us a most eminent example of justice towards an enemy;
tgt_text.282: for when a deserter from Pyrrhus offered to the senate to despatch that prince by poison, the senate and C. Fabricius delivered the traitor up to Pyrrhus.
tgt_text.283: Thus they disapproved of taking off by treachery an enemy who was powerful, and was carrying on against them an aggressive war.
tgt_text.284: Enough has now been said respecting the duties connected with warfare ;
tgt_text.285: but we must bear in mind, that justice is due even to the lowest of mankind ;
tgt_text.286: and nothing can be lower than the condition and fortune of a slave.
tgt_text.287: And yet those prescribe wisely who enjoin us to put them upon the same footing as hired labourers, obliging them to do their work, but giving them their dues.
tgt_text.288: Now, as injustice may be done two ways, by force or fraud ;
tgt_text.289: fraud being the property of a fox, force that of a lion ;
tgt_text.290: both are utterly repugnant to society, but fraud is the more detestable.
tgt_text.291: But in the whole system of villainy, none is more capital than that of the men, who, when they most deceive, so manage as that they may seem to be virtuous men.
tgt_text.292: Thus much, then, on the subject of justice.
tgt_text.294: Let me now, as I proposed, speak of beneficence and liberality, virtues that are the most agreeable to the nature of man, but which involve many precautionary con- siderations.
tgt_text.295: For, in the first place, we are to take care lest our kindness should hurt both those whom it is meant to assist, and others.
tgt_text.296: In the next place, it ought not to exceed our abilities;
tgt_text.297: and it ought to be rendered to each in proportion to his worth.
tgt_text.298: This is the fundamental standard of justice to which all these things should be referred.
tgt_text.299: And they who do kindnesses which prove of disservice to the person they pretend to oblige, should not be esteemed beneficent nor generous, but injurious sycophants.
tgt_text.300: And they who injure one party in order to be liberal to another, are guilty of the same dishonesty as if they should appropriate to themselves what belongs to another.
tgt_text.301: *Now many, and they especially who are the most ambitious after grandeur and glory, rob one party to enrich another ;
tgt_text.302: and account themselves generous to their friends if they enrich them by whatever means.
tgt_text.303: This is so far from being consistent with, that nothing can be more contrary to, our duty.
tgt_text.304: We should therefore take care to practise that kind of generosity that is serviceable to our friends, but hurtful to none.
tgt_text.305: Upon this principle, when Lucius Sylla and Caius Cæsar took property from its just owners and transferred it to strangers, in so doing they ought not to be accounted generous ;
tgt_text.306: for nothing can be generous that is not at the same time just.
tgt_text.307: Our next part of circumspection is, that our generosity never should exceed our abilities.
tgt_text.308: For they who are more generous than their circumstances admit of are, first, guilty in this, that they wrong their relations;
tgt_text.309: because they bestow upon strangers those means which they might, with greater justice, give or leave to those who are nearest to them.
tgt_text.310: Now a generosity of this kind is generally attended with a lust to ravish and to plunder, in order to be furnished with the means to give away.
tgt_text.311: For it is easy to observe, that most of them are not so much by nature generous, as they are misled by a kind of pride to do a great many things in order that they may seem to be generous ;
tgt_text.312: which things seem to spring not so much from good will as from osten- tation.
tgt_text.313: Now such a simulation is more nearly allied to duplicity than to generosity or virtue.
tgt_text.314: The third head proposed was, that in our generosity we should have regard to merit;
tgt_text.315: and, consequently, examine both the morals of the party to whom we are generous, and his disposition towards us, together with the general good of society, and how far he may have already contributed to our own interest.
tgt_text.316: Could all those considerations be united, it were the more desirable ;
tgt_text.317: but the object in whom is united the most numerous and the most important of them, ought to have the greatest weight with us.XV.
tgt_text.318: But as we live not with men who are absolutely perfect and completely wise, but with men who have great merit if they possess the outlines of worth, we are, I think, from thence to infer, that no man is to be neglected in whom there appears any indication of virtue ;
tgt_text.319: and that each should be regarded in proportion as he is adorned with the milder virtues of modesty, temperance, and that very justice of which I have so largely treated.
tgt_text.320: For fortitude and greatness of spirit is commonly too violent in a man who is not com- pletely wise and perfect;
tgt_text.321: but the aforesaid virtues seem to belong more to a good man.
tgt_text.322: Having said thus much of morals ;
tgt_text.323: with regard to the kindness which a person expresses for us, our first duty is, to perform the most for him by whom we are most beloved.
tgt_text.324: Now we are to judge of kindness, not like children, by a sort of ardour of affection, but by its stability and constancy.
tgt_text.325: But if its merits are such, that we are not to court but to requite the kindness, the greater ought our care to be;
tgt_text.326: for there is no duty more indispensable than that of returning a kind- ness.
tgt_text.327: Now if, as Hesiod enjoins, we ought, if it is in our power, to repay what we have received for mere use with interest, how ought we to act when called upon by kindness ?
tgt_text.328: Are we not to imitate those fertile fields which yield far more than they have received ?
tgt_text.329: For, if we readily oblige those who we are in hopes will serve us, how ought we to behave towards those who have served us already ?
tgt_text.330: For as generosity is of two kinds, the one conferring a favour, the other repaying it, whether we confer it or not is at our own option, but the not repaying it is not allowable in a good man, provided he can do so without injury to any.
tgt_text.331: Now there are distinctions to be made as to the benefits received ;
tgt_text.332: and it is clear that the greatest return is due in each case to the greatest obligation.
tgt_text.333: Meanwhile, we are above all things to consider the spirit, the zeal, and the meaning with which a favour is conferred.
tgt_text.334: For many confer numerous favours with a sort of recklessness, without any judgment or prin- ciple, upon all mankind promiscuously, or influenced by sudden perturbation of mind, as if by a hurricane :
tgt_text.335: such favours are not to be esteemed so highly as those which result from judgment, consideration, and consistency.
tgt_text.336: But in conferring or requiting kindness, the chief rule of our duty ought to be, if all other circumstances are equal, to confer most upon the man who stands in greatest need of assistance.
tgt_text.337: The reverse of this is practised by the generality, who direct their greatest services to the man from whom they hope the most, though he may stand in no need of them.
tgt_text.339: Now society and alliances amongst men would be best preserved if the greatest kindness should be manifested where there is the nearest relation.
tgt_text.340: But we ought to go higher, if we are to investigate the natural principles of intercourse and community amongst men.
tgt_text.341: The first is, that which is perceived in the society of the whole human race.
tgt_text.342: and of this the bond is speech and reason, which by teaching, learning, communicating, debating, and judging, conciliate men together, and bind them into a kind of natural society.
tgt_text.343: There is nothing in which we differ more from the nature of brutes than in tills ;
tgt_text.344: for we very often allow them to have courage, as for instance, horses and lions;
tgt_text.345: but we never admit that they possess justice, equity, and goodness ;
tgt_text.346: because they are void of reason and speech.
tgt_text.347: Now this is the kind of society that is most extensive with mankind amongst themselves, and it goes through all;
tgt_text.348: for here a community of all things that nature has produced for the common use of mankind is preserved, so as that they may be possessed in the manner prescribed by laws and civil statutes:
tgt_text.349: of which laws themselves some are to be observed in accordance with the Greek proverb, "that all things amongst friends are to be in common."
tgt_text.350: Now this community consists of things which are of that nature which, though placed by Ennius under one head, may be applied to many. " He (says that author) who kindly shows the bewildered traveller the right road.
tgt_text.351: does as it were light his lamp by his own ;
tgt_text.352: which affords none the less light to himself after it has lighted the other.
tgt_text.353: "By this single example he sufficiently enjoins on us to perform, even to a stranger, all the service we can do without detriment to ourselves.
tgt_text.354: Of which service the following are common illustrations :
tgt_text.355: "That we are to debar no man from the running stream;
tgt_text.357: That we are to suffer any who desire it to kindle fire at our fire "
tgt_text.358: That we are to give faithful counsel to a person who is in doubt:
tgt_text.359: " all which are particulars that are serviceable to the receiver without being detrimental to the bestower.
tgt_text.360: We are therefore to practise them, and be constantly contributing somewhat to the common good.
tgt_text.361: As the means, however, of each par- ticular person are very confined and the numbers of the indigent are boundless, our distributive generosity ought still to be bounded by the principle of Ennius,—"it nevertheless gives light to one's self,"—that we may still be possessed of the means to be generous to our friends.
tgt_text.363: Now the degrees of human society are many.
tgt_text.364: For, to quit the foregoing unbounded kind, there is one more confined, which consists of men of the same race, nation, and language, by which people are more intimately connected among themselves.
tgt_text.365: A more contracted society than that consists of men inhabiting the same city;
tgt_text.366: for many things are in common among fellow citizens, such as their forum, their temples, their porticoes, their streets, their laws, their rites, their courts of justice, their trials, not to mention their customs, and intimacies, with a great number of particular dealings and intercourses of numbers with numbers.
tgt_text.367: There is a still more contracted degree of society, which is that of relatives;
tgt_text.368: and this closes, in a narrow point, the unbounded general association of the human race.
tgt_text.369: For, as it is a common natural principle among all animated beings that they have a desire to propagate their own species, the first principle of society consists in the marriage tie, the next in children, the next in a family within one roof, where everything is in common.
tgt_text.370: This society gives rise to the city, and Is, as it were, the nursery of the commonwealth.
tgt_text.371: Next follows the connexion of brotherhood, next that of cousins, in their different degrees;
tgt_text.372: and, when they grow too numerous to be contained under one roof, they are trans- planted to different dwellings, as it were to so many colonies.
tgt_text.373: Then follow marriages and alliances, whence spring more numerous relationships.
tgt_text.374: The descendants, by this propa- gation, form the origin of commonwealths;
tgt_text.375: but the ties and affections of blood bind mankind by affection.
tgt_text.376: *For there is something very powerful in having the monu- merits of our ancestors the same, in practising the same religious rites, and in having the same places of interment.
tgt_text.377: But amongst all the degrees of society, none is more excel- lent, none more stable, than when worthy meu, through a similarity of manners, are intimately connected together;
tgt_text.378: for, as I have often said, even when we discern the honestum in another it touches us, and makes us friends to the man in whom it resides.
tgt_text.379: Now, though virtue of every kind attracts and charms us to the love of those who possess it, yet that love is strongest that is effected by justice and generosity.
tgt_text.380: For nothing is more lovely, nothing is more binding, than a similarity of good dispositions;
tgt_text.381: * because amongst those whose pursuits and pleasures are the same, every man is pleased as much with another as he is with himself, and that is effected which Pythagoras chiefly contemplates in friendship, "that many become one."
tgt_text.382: A strong community is likewise effected by good offices mutually conferred and received;
tgt_text.383: and, provided these be reciprocal and agreeable, those amongst whom they happen are bound together in close association.
tgt_text.384: But when you view everything with reason and reflection, of all connections none is more weighty, none is more dear, than that between every individual and his country.
tgt_text.385: Our parents are dear to us;
tgt_text.386: our children, our kinsmen, our friends, are dear to us;
tgt_text.387: but our country comprehends alone all the endearments of us all.
tgt_text.388: For which what good man would hesitate to die if he could do her service ?
tgt_text.389: The more execrably unnatural, therefore, are they who wound their country by every species of guilt, and who are now, and have been, employed in her utter destruction.
tgt_text.390: But were a computation or comparison set up, of those objects to which our chief duty should be paid, the principal are our country and our parents, by whose services we are laid under the strongest obligations;
tgt_text.391: the next are our children and entire family, who depend upon us alone, without having any other refuge;
tgt_text.392: the next our agreeable kinsmen, who generally share our fortuue in common.
tgt_text.393: The necessary supports of life, therefore, are due chiefly to those I have already mentioned ;
tgt_text.394: but the mutual intercourses of life, counsels, discourses, ex- hortations, consultations, and even sometimes reproofs, flourish chiefly in friendships, and those friendships are the most agreeable that are cemented by a similarity of manners.
tgt_text.396: But in performing all those duties we are care- fully to consider what is most necessary to each, and what every one of them could or could not attain even without us.
tgt_text.397: Thus the relative claims of relationship and of circumstances will not always be identical.
tgt_text.398: Some duties are owing to some more than to others.
tgt_text.399: For instance, you are sooner to help your neighbour to house his corn, than your brother or your friend;
tgt_text.400: but if a cause be on trial, you are to take part with your kinsman, or your friend, rather than with your neigh- bour.
tgt_text.401: These considerations, therefore, and the like, ought to be carefully observed in every duty;
tgt_text.402: and custom and practice should be attained, that we may be able to be correct assessors of our duties, and, by adding or subtracting, to strike the balance, by which we may see the proportion to which every party is entitled.
tgt_text.403: But as neither physicians, nor generals, nor orators, how- ever perfect they may be in the theory of their art, can ever perform anything that is highly praiseworthy, without expe- rience and practice, so rules have indeed been laid down for the observation of duties, as I myself am doing;
tgt_text.404: but the import- ance of the matter demands experience and practice.
tgt_text.405: I have now, I think, sufficiently treated of the manner in which the honestum, which gives the fitness to our duties, arises from those matters that come within the rights of human society.
tgt_text.406: It must be understood, however, at the same time, that when the four springs from which virtue and honesty, arise are laid open, that which is done with a lofty spirit, and one which scorns ordinary interests, appears the most noble.
tgt_text.407: Therefore the most natural of all reproaches is somewhat of the following kind:
tgt_text.408: - Young men, ye carry but the souls of women;
tgt_text.410: Or somewhat of the following kind:
tgt_text.411: - Salmacis, give me spoils without toil or danger.
tgt_text.412: On the other hand, in our praises, I know not how it is, but actions performed with magnanimity, with fortitude, and virtue, we eulogize in a loftier style.
tgt_text.413: From hence Marathon, Salamis, Platæa, Thermopylae, Leuctra, have become the field of rhetoricians;
tgt_text.414: and amongst ourselves, Cocles, the Decii, the two Scipios, Cneius and Publius, Marcus Marcellus, and a great many others.
tgt_text.415: Indeed, the Roman people in general are distinguished above all by elevation of spirit;
tgt_text.416: and their fondness for military glory is shown by the fact that we generally see their statues dressed in warlike habits.
tgt_text.418: But that magnanimity which is discovered in toils and dangers, if it be devoid of justice, and contend not for the public good, but for selfish interest, is blameable ;
tgt_text.419: for, so far from being a mark of virtue, it is rather that of a barbarity which is repulsive to all humanity.
tgt_text.420: By the Stoics, therefore, fortitude is rightly defined, when they call it valour fighting on the side of justice."
tgt_text.421: No man, there- fore, who has acquired the reputation of fortitude, attained his glory by deceit and malice;
tgt_text.422: for nothing that is devoid of justice can be a virtue.
tgt_text.423: It is, therefore, finely said by Plato, that not only the knowledge that is apart from justice deserves the appellation of cunning rather than wisdom, but also a mind that is ready to encounter danger, if it is animated by private interest, and not public utility, deserves the character of audaciousness rather than of fortitude.
tgt_text.424: We, therefore, require that all men of courage and magnanimity should be at the same time men of virtue and of simplicity, lovers of truth, and by no means deceitful;
tgt_text.425: for these qualities are the main glory of justice.
tgt_text.426: But there is one painful consideration, that obstinacy, and an undue ambition for power, naturally spring up from this elevation and greatness of spirit;
tgt_text.427: for, as Plato tells us, the entire character of the Lacedemonians was inflamed with the desire of conquest.
tgt_text.428: Thus the man who is most distin- guished by his magnanimity, is most desirous of being the leading, or rather the only potentate of all.
tgt_text.429: Now, it is a difficult matter, when you desire to be superior to all others, to preserve that equability which is the characteristic or justice.
tgt_text.430: Hence it is that such men will not suffer themselves to be thwarted in a debate, nor by any public and lawful authority;
tgt_text.431: and in public matters they are commonly guilty of corruption and faction, in order to grasp at as great power as possible;
tgt_text.432: and they choose to be superior by means of force, rather than equals by justice.
tgt_text.433: But the more diffi- cult the matter is, it is the more glorious;
tgt_text.434: for there is no conjuncture which ought to be unconnected with justice.
tgt_text.435: They, therefore, who oppose, not they who commit, in- justice are to be deemed brave and magnanimous.
tgt_text.436: Now, genuine and well-considered magnanimity judges that the honestum, which is nature's chief aim, consists in realities and not in mere glory, and rather chooses to be than to seem pre-eminent:
tgt_text.437: for the man who is swayed by the pre- judices of an ignorant rabble is not to be reckoned among the great;
tgt_text.438: but the man of a spirit the most elevated, through the desire of glory, is the most easily impelled into acts of injustice.
tgt_text.439: This is, indeed, a slippery situation;
tgt_text.440: for scarcely can there be found a man who, after enduring trials and encountering dangers, does not pant for popularity as the reward of his exploits.*XX.
tgt_text.441: A spirit altogether brave and elevated is chiefly dis- cernible by two characters.
tgt_text.442: The first consists in a low estimate of mere outward circumstances, since it is convinced that a man ought to admire, desire, or court nothing but what is virtuous and becoming;
tgt_text.443: and that he ought to succumb to no man, nor to any perturbation either of spirit or fortune.*
tgt_text.444: The other thing is, that possessed of such a spirit as I have just mentioned, you should perform actions which are great and of the greatest utility, but extremely arduous, full of difficulties and danger both to life and the many things which pertain to life.
tgt_text.445: In the latter of those two characters consist all the glory, the majesty, and, I add, the utility;
tgt_text.446: but the causes and the efficient means that form great men is in the former, which contains the principles that elevate the soul, and gives it a contempt for temporary considerations.
tgt_text.447: Now, this very excel- lence consists in two particulars:
tgt_text.448: you are to deem that only to be good that is virtuous;
tgt_text.449: and that you be free from all mental irregularity.
tgt_text.450: For we are to look upon it as the character of a noble and an elevated soul, to slight all those considerations that the generality of mankind account great and glorious, and to despise them, upon firm and durable principles;
tgt_text.451: while strength of mind, and greatness of resolution, are discerned in bearing those calamities which, in the course of man's life, are many and various, so as not to be driven from your na- tural disposition, nor from the dignity of a wise man:
tgt_text.452: for it is not consistent that he who is not subdued by fear should be subjugated by passion ;
tgt_text.453: nor that he who has shown him- self invincible by toil, should be conquered by pleasure.
tgt_text.455: Wherefore, we ought to watch and avoid the love of money:
tgt_text.456: for nothing so truly characterizes a narrow, grovelling dispo- sition as to love riches;
tgt_text.457: * and nothing is more noble and more exalted than to despise riches if you have them not, and if you have them, to employ them in beneficence and libe- rality.
tgt_text.458: †An inordinate passion for glory, as I have already ob- served, is likewise to be guarded against;
tgt_text.459: for it deprives us of liberty, the only prize for which men of elevated senti- ments ought to contend.
tgt_text.460: Power is so far from being desirable in itself, that it sometimes ought to be refused, and some- times to be resigned.
tgt_text.461: We should likewise be free from all disorders of the mind, from all violent passion and fear, as well as languor, voluptuousness, and anger, that we may possess that tranquillity and security which confer alike consistency and dignity.
tgt_text.462: Now, many there are, and have been, who, courting that tranquillity which I have mentioned here, have withdrawn themselves from public affairs and taken refuge in retirement.
tgt_text.463: Amongst these, some of the noblest and most leading of our philosophers;
tgt_text.464: ‡ and some persons, of strict and grave dispositions, were unable to bear with the manners either of the people or their rulers;
tgt_text.465: and some have lived in the country, amusing themselves with the management of their private affairs.
tgt_text.466: Their aim was the same as that of the powerful, that they might enjoy their liberty, without wanting anything or obeying any person;
tgt_text.467: for the essence of liberty is to live just as you please.
tgt_text.469: Therefore, as the object of those who are ambitious for power, and of those who court retirement, and whom I have just now described, is the same, the former imagine they can attain it if they are possessed of great resources, and the latter, if they can be contented with their own, and with little.
tgt_text.470: In this matter, the sentiments of neither are to be absolutely rejected.
tgt_text.471: But a life of retirement is more easy, more safe, less tiresome, and less troublesome than any other;
tgt_text.472: while the life of those who apply themselves to the affairs of government, and to the management of a state, is more beneficial to mankind, and more conducive to glory and renown.
tgt_text.473: Allowances, therefore, are to be made for those who having no management in public matters, with an excellent genius, give themselves up to learning;
tgt_text.474: and to those who being hindered by feebleness of health, or for some very weighty reason, retire from affairs of government, and leave to others the power and the honour of the administration:
tgt_text.475: but when men, who have no such excuses, say that they despise that power and those offices which most admire, such men are so far from deserving praise that they incur censure.
tgt_text.476: It is difficult to condemn their judgment in despising and under- valuing popularity;
tgt_text.477: but then they seem to dread the toils and troubles of affronts and repulses as involving ignominy and infamy.
tgt_text.478: For some there are who, in opposite matters, are very inconsistent with themselves;
tgt_text.479: they spurn most rigidly at pleasure, but they droop in pain;
tgt_text.480: they despise glory, but sink under unpopularity;
tgt_text.481: and that, too, with no little inconsistency.
tgt_text.482: But the men who inherit from nature appliances for government ought, laying aside all excuses, to undertake the discharge of all public offices and the management of state affairs;
tgt_text.483: for neither can a state be governed, nor can magna- nimity display itself, by any other means.
tgt_text.484: I am not, however, sure whether those who undertake the management of public affairs ought not to be equally distinguished by magnanimity us philosophers, if not more so, and impressed with a con- tempt of common affairs and to possess that tranquillity, that calm of mind, I have so much recommended;
tgt_text.485: I mean, if they wish to live without anxiety, with dignity and consistency.
tgt_text.486: This may be the more easily practised by philosophers, because in their lives there is less exposed for fortune to strike at;
tgt_text.487: because their necessities are more contracted;
tgt_text.488: and because, if anything adverse should happen, they cannot fall so heavily.
tgt_text.489: It is not, therefore, without reason, that in the mind of those who undertake the management of public affairs, more violent passions are excited, and mightier mat- ters are to be attempted, than by those who are retired;
tgt_text.490: they, therefore, ought to possess greater elevation of spirit, and freedom from disquiets.
tgt_text.491: But, whoever enters upon public life ought to take care that the question, how far the measure is virtuous, be not his sole consideration, but also how far he may have the means of carrying it into execution.
tgt_text.492: In this he is chiefly to take care that through indolence he do not meanly despond, nor through eagerness too much pre- sume.
tgt_text.493: Thus, in all affairs, before you undertake them, a diligent preparation should be entered into.
tgt_text.495: But, since most persons are of opinion that the achievements of war are more glorious than civil affairs, this judgment needs to be restricted:
tgt_text.496: for many, as generally is the case with high minds and enterprising spirits, espe- cially if they are adapted to military life and are fond of warlike achievements, have often sought opportunities of war from their fondness for glory;
tgt_text.497: but if we are willing to judge truly, many are the civil employments of greater im- portance, and of more renown, than the military.
tgt_text.498: For though Themistocles is justly praised-his name is now more illustrious than that of Solon, and his glorious victory at Salamis is mentioned preferably to the policy of Solon, by which he first confirmed the power of the Areopagus -the one should not be considered more illustrious than the other;
tgt_text.499: for the one availed his country only for once-the other is lastingly advantageous;
tgt_text.500: because by it the laws of the Athenians, and the institutions of their ancestors, are preserved.
tgt_text.502: Themistocles could not have stated any respect in which he benefited the Areopagus, but the former might with truth declare that Themistocles had been advan- taged by him;
tgt_text.503: for the war was carried on by the counsels of that senate which was constituted by Solon.
tgt_text.504: We may make the same observation with regard to Pausanias and Lysander amongst the Lacedemonians ;
tgt_text.505: for all the addition of empire which their conquests are supposed to have brought to their country is not to be compared to the laws and economy of Lycurgus ;
tgt_text.506: for indeed, owing to these very causes they had armies more subordinate and courageous.
tgt_text.507: In my eyes, Marcus Scaurus (who flourished when I was but a boy) was not inferior to Caius Marius;
tgt_text.508: nor, after I came to have a concern in the government, Quintus Catulus to Cneius Pompey.
tgt_text.509: An army abroad is but of small service unless there be a wise administration at home.
tgt_text.510: Nor did that good man and great general, Africanus, perform a more important service to his country when he razed Numantia, than did that private citizen, P. Nasica, when at the same period he killed Tiberius Gracchus.
tgt_text.511: An action which it is true was not merely of a civil nature ;
tgt_text.512: for it approaches to a military character, as being the result of force and courage ;
tgt_text.513: but it was an action performed without an army, and from political considerations.
tgt_text.514: That state described by the following line is best for a country, for which I understand that I am abused by the wicked and malicious:
tgt_text.515: Arms to the gown, and laurels yield to lore.
tgt_text.516: *For, not to mention other persons, when I was at the helm of government did not "arms yield to the gown?"
tgt_text.517: For never did our country know a time of more threatening danger or more profound tranquillity;
tgt_text.518: so quickly, through my counsel and my diligence, did the arms of our most pro- fligate fellow citizens drop of themselves out of their hands.
tgt_text.519: What so great exploit as this was ever performed in wai, or what triumph can be compared with it ?
tgt_text.520: The inheritance of my glory and the imitation of my actions are to descend to you, my son Marcus, therefore it is allowable for me to boast in writing to you.
tgt_text.521: It is, how- ever, certain that Pompey, who was possessed of much military glory, paid this tribute to me, in the hearing of many, that in vain would he have returned to his third triumph, had not my public services preserved the place in which he was to celebrate it.
tgt_text.522: The examples of civil courage are therefore no less meritorious than those of mili- tary ;
tgt_text.523: and they require a greater share of zeal and labour than the latter.
tgt_text.525: Now all that excellence which springs from a lofty and noble nature is altogether produced by the mental and not by the corporeal powers.*
tgt_text.526: Meanwhile, the body ought to be kept in such action and order, as that it may be always ready to obey the dictates of reason and wisdom, in carrying them into execution, and in persevering under hardships.
tgt_text.527: But with regard to that honestum we are treating of, it consists wholly in the thoughtful application of the mind ;
tgt_text.528: by which the civilians who preside over public affairs are equally serviceable to their country as they who wage wars.
tgt_text.529: For it often happens that by such counsels wars are either not entered into, or they are brought to a termination ;
tgt_text.530: sometimes they are even undertaken, as the third Punic wale was by the advice of Marcus Cato, whose authority was powerful, even after he was dead.
tgt_text.531: Wisdom in determining is therefore preferable tc courage in fighting ;
tgt_text.532: but in this we are to take care that we are not swayed by an aversion to fighting rather than by a consideration of expediency.*
tgt_text.533: Now in engaging in war we ought to make it appear that we have no other view but peace.
tgt_text.534: But the character of a brave and resolute man is not to be ruffled with adversity, and not to be in such confusion as to quit his post, as we say, but to preserve a presence of mind, and the exercise of reason, without departing from his purpose.
tgt_text.535: And while this is the charac- teristic of a lofty spirit, so this also is that of a powerful intellect, namely, to anticipate futurity in thought, and to conclude beforehand what may happen on either side, and, upon that, what measures to pursue, and never be surprised so as to say, "I had not thought of that."
tgt_text.536: Such are the operations of a genius, capacious and elevated ;
tgt_text.537: of such a one as relies on its own prudence and counsel ;
tgt_text.538: † but to rush precipitately into the field, and to encounter an enemy with mere physical force has somewhat in it that is barbarous and brutal.
tgt_text.539: When the occasion, however, and its necessity compel it, we should resist with force, and prefer death to slavery or dishonour.
tgt_text.541: But with regard to overthrowing and plundering of cities, great consideration is required that nothing be done rashly, nothing cruelly.*
tgt_text.542: And this is the part of a great man, after he has maturely weighed all circumstances, to punish the guilty, to spare the many ;
tgt_text.543: and in every state of fortune not to depart from an upright, virtuous conduct.
